|t4={{linktext|定縣}} |p4=Dìngxiàn |psp4=Tingsien |w4=Ting-hsien]] }} '''Dingzhou''',<!--Chinese in infobox; see WP:MOS-ZH--> or '''Tingchow''' in [[Postal Map Romanization]], and formerly called '''Ding County''' or '''Dingxian''', is a [[county-level city]] in the [[prefecture-level city]] of [[Baoding]], [[Hebei|Hebei Province]]. As of 2009, Dingzhou had a population of 1.2 million. Dingzhou has 3 [[Subdistrict (China)|subdistricts]], 13 towns, 8 townships, and 1 ethnic township.<ref name = "Admin Div">[http://www.xzqh.org/html/list/764.html 定州市-行政区网]</ref> Dingzhou is about halfway between Baoding and [[Shijiazhuang]], {{convert|196|km|sp=us}} southwest of [[Beijing]], and {{convert|68|km|sp=us}} northeast of Shijiazhuang.
==History== Dingzhou was originally known as '''Lunu''' in early [[imperial China]].<ref name=bearman/> A tomb about {{convert|4|km|sp=us}} southwest of Dingzhou from 55{{nbsp}}{{sc|bce}} was discovered and excavated in 1973. It contained several fragments of [[Chinese literature|Han literature]], including [[manuscript]]s of [[Confucius]]'s ''[[Analects]]'', the [[Taoism in China|Taoist]] ''[[Wenzi]]'', and the ''[[Six Secret Teachings]]'', a military treatise.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Dingzhou took its present name around 400{{nbsp}}{{sc|ce}} when it became the seat of [[Ding Prefecture]] under the [[Northern Wei]], displacing the earlier [[Anzhou (Northern China)|An Prefecture]].<ref name=bearman>{{harvp|Xiong|2017|loc="[https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=fCdCDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA137 Dingzhou]"}}.</ref> In the mid-6th century, its territory held 834,211 people living in 177,500 [[households]].<ref name=bearman/> Under the [[Sui dynasty|Sui]], the seat of [[Boling Commandery]] at present-day [[Anping, Hebei|Anping]] was renamed "Gaoyang". In 607, Dingzhou then became the eponymous seat of a new '''Boling''' [[jun (country subdivision)|commandery]] and retained that name and status under the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]]<ref>{{citation |contribution=Boling |contribution-url=https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=fCdCDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA69 |p=[https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=fCdCDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA69 69] |url=https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=fCdCDgAAQBAJ |title=Historical Dictionary of Medieval China |last=Xiong |first=Victor Cunrui |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |location=[[Lanham, Maryland|Lanham]] |date=2017 |isbn=9781442276154 }}.</ref> until it returned to the name Dingzhou between 621 and 742 and again after 758.<ref name=bearman/> Its territory held only 86,869 people in 25,637 households in 639 but recovered to 496,676 people in 78,090 households by 742.<ref name=bearman/>
In 1055, under the [[Song dynasty|Song]], the city became the home of the {{convert|84|m|ft|sp=us|adj=mid|-tall}} [[Liaodi Pagoda]], which is today China's tallest surviving pre-modern [[pagoda]].
Under the [[Republic of China (1912-1949)|early Republic]], it was known as '''Dingxian''' ([[Postal Map Romanization|then romanized]] "Tingsien" or "Ting Hsien") from its status as the seat of [[Ding County]]. From 1926 to 1937, the county was the site of the [[National Association of Mass Education Movement]]'s [[Ting Hsien Experiment]] of the [[Rural Reconstruction Movement]]. In the 1990s, the [[New Rural Reconstruction Movement]] maintained a training and outreach center.
